Literature Review: Atomic hydrogen (Hi) plays a crucial role in the evolution of galaxies, serving as a tracer of the interstellar medium (ISM) and its various phases. The ISM is a complex, dynamic system that undergoes significant changes throughout the galaxy's lifetime, and Hi is an essential component of this process. In this review, we will discuss the latest findings on Hi in the Milky Way, including its physical properties, structure, and association with magnetic fields. We will also explore how Hi properties depend on the environment and what its structure can tell us about feedback in the ISM.The mass fraction of the cold neutral medium is a critical parameter in understanding the evolution of galaxies. Studies have shown that the mass fraction of the cold neutral medium is ≲40% on average, increasing with A_V due to the increase of mean gas density. This suggests that the cold neutral medium is a significant component of the ISM, and its properties are closely tied to the galaxy's evolution.The structure of Hi in the Milky Way is also an important area of research. Recent surveys have revealed that the cold disk extends to at least R ∼ 25 kpc, indicating that Hi is present throughout the galaxy. Additionally, approximately 40% of the Hi is warm, with structural characteristics that derive from feedback events. This suggests that feedback plays a significant role in shaping the structure of the ISM.The filamentary structure of cold Hi is also an interesting area of research. Studies have shown that cold Hi is highly filamentary, whereas warm Hi is more smoothly distributed. This suggests that the structure of Hi is closely tied to the galaxy's evolution and the processes that shape the ISM.Magnetic fields are also an important component of the ISM, and their association with Hi is a key area of research. Studies have shown that magnetic fields are present throughout the galaxy, and their association with Hi can provide valuable insights into the galaxy's evolution. The structure of Hi can also provide clues about the effects of heating and cooling on Hi properties.In conclusion, the study of Hi in the Milky Way is a complex and multifaceted field that requires a comprehensive understanding of the ISM and its various phases. The latest findings on Hi properties, structure, and association with magnetic fields provide valuable insights into the galaxy's evolution and the processes that shape the ISM. Future observational and simulation opportunities will be critical in unraveling the 3D structure of the atomic ISM and the effects of heating and cooling on Hi properties.
